STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 16, 2020
Kelli Arrendondo
Catholic Charities West Michigan - GR
40 Jefferson Avenue, SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49503-4304
RE: License #: CB410245705
Catholic Charities West Michigan - GR
40 Jefferson Avenue, SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49503-4304
Dear Ms. Arrendondo:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
December 15, 2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MISEP. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Repeat violations require an explanation on why the previous corrective
action plan was not successful.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Jessica VandenHeuvel, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(616) 204-6992
enclosure
Alisa Otto, Licensee Designee
Kelli Smith, Board President
WMPC

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
Three of seven foster home files reviewed requiring a renewal inspection did not
provide the application at least 60 days prior to the license expiration date.
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(2) The foster parent training plan shall provide for all of the
following:
(c) Not less than 6 hours of training annually for each
licensee after the time periods specified in subdivisions (b) of
this subrule.
One of eight foster home files reviewed lacked adequate six hours of annual training
as required. The six hours consisted of the foster family watching three movies.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) For a child under 2 years of age, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 3 months before
being placed in foster care or a new physical examination shall
be completed within 30 calendar days after being placed in
foster care.
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months before
placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
4

One of five foster youth files reviewed lacked a physical examination being
completed within 30 days of entering foster care as required.
One of six foster youth files reviewed lacked a physical examination being
completed every 14 months as required.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least every
18 months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
One of five foster youth files reviewed lacked a dental examination being completed
with 90 day of entering foster care as required.
One of nine foster youth files reviewed lacked a dental examination being completed
every six months as required (See Communication Issuance 19-114)
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
One of two independent living youth files reviewed where a youth entered
independent living during this period under review lacked documentation the
program statement was provided to the youth as required.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency's policies and procedures required by this
rule.
One of two independent living youth files reviewed where a youth entered
independent living during this period under review lacked documentation the policies
and procedures were provided to the youth as required.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between the
youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
(b) A plan for education or work.
5

(c) An agreement for the youth to meet with the worker at
least one time per calendar month.
(d) The location where the youth is living.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Three of three independent living youth files reviewed lacked the independent
contract as required. Two of those three had no independent living contract located
in the file. The third file only had one independent living contract, lacking completion
of one every 90 calendar days.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
Two of six adoption applicant files reviewed lacked a completed written adoptive
evaluation within 90 days of the family signing the application.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report, CAP approved 1/17/20
2018 Renewal Inspection Report, CAP Approved 1/16/19
R 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption with a
signed and dated copy of the evaluation and recommendation
upon its completion.
One of six adoption applicant files reviewed did not provide the applicants with the
evaluation and recommendation upon its completion.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.19 Assessments and Service Plans, Content
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
6

Seven of eleven open foster care files reviewed lacked the required signatures on
the case service plans.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report, CAP approved 1/17/20
2018 Renewal Inspection Report, CAP Approved 1/16/19 (cited ISEP 6.33)
ISEP 6.24 Visits, Between Siblings
(a) DHHS shall ensure that children in foster care who have
siblings in custody with whom they are not placed shall have
at least monthly visits with their siblings who are placed
elsewhere in DHHS foster care custody. Exceptions to this
requirement are cases in which:
(1) the visit may be harmful to one or more of the siblings;
(2) the sibling is placed out of state in compliance with the
Interstate Compact on Placement of Children;
(3) the distance between the children's placements is more
than 50 miles and the child is placed with a relative; or
(4) one of the siblings is above the age of 16 and refuses
such visits.
(b) All exceptions and all reasonable steps taken to assure that
visits take place shall be documented in the case file.
Two of four open foster care files reviewed where siblings were not placed together,
the monthly sibling visits were not occurring each month as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report, CAP approved 1/17/20
2018 Renewal Inspection Report, CAP Approved 1/16/19 (Cited ISEP 6.42)
ISEP 6.22 Visits, Worker-Parent
(2) for each subsequent month, at least one face-to-face contact
with each parent and phone contact as needed, with at least on
contact in each three-month period occurring in the parent’s
place of residence.
Four of six open foster care case files with the goal of reunification reviewed lacked
documentation of the required worker-parent contact each month.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report, CAP approved 1/17/20
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Policy violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Policy requirements that may not be included in section
7

1. The facility is in compliance will all additional MDHHS Policy requirements except
for the following:
FOM 722-8C Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service Agreement
Signatures
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS
office designee.
Four of six open foster care files lacked the foster parent signature on the parent
agency treatment plan.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report, CAP approved 1/17/20
2018 Renewal Inspection Report, CAP Approved 1/16/19
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Types and Timeframes
FTMs must occur within the required time frames.
Post FTM
 Providing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, to all participants (in person and by phone),
legal parents, and casework supervisor. These
documents must also be uploaded into MISACWIS.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven business
days of the FTM.
8

Three of eleven files reviewed lacked documentation that a Case Plan
Development/Reassessment Family Team Meeting was completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report, CAP approved 1/17/20
2018 Renewal Inspection Report, CAP Approved 1/16/19
One of eleven foster care files reviewed lacked the required DHS 1105 Activity
Report uploaded into MiSACWIS as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report, CAP approved 1/17/20
One file lacked a semi-annual transition plan family team meetings every six
months as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report, CAP approved 1/17/20
FOM 722-8 Foster Care- Initial Service Plan
Supervisory Approval
Prior to finalizing, the ISP along with the required
assessments must be reviewed and approved by the foster
care supervisor only after a face-to-face meeting with the
foster care worker.
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
 Review and approve the ISP within 14 calendar days of
the Report Date.
One of five open files reviewed where an initial service plan was completed was
not approved by the supervisor within 14 days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report, CAP approved 1/17/20
2018 Renewal Inspection Report, CAP Approved 1/16/19
FOM 722-6H Caseworker Contact
Caseworker contact with children in out of home placement.
First Two Months after Initial Placement or a Placement
Move
9

The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts per
month with the child for the first two months following an initial
placement or a placement move.
NOTE: A month is defined as 30 calendar days, unless
otherwise specified; for example, calendar month.
Subsequent Months
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact with
the child each calendar month. At least one contact each
calendar month must take place at the child’s placement
location. Each contact must include a private meeting between
the child and the caseworker; see Private Meeting in this item.
One of eleven open foster care files reviewed lacked documentation of the worker
having two visits for the first two months of placement.
One of eleven open foster care files reviewed lacked documentation of the worker
having one face to face visit with the youth in subsequent months.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report, CAP approved 1/17/20
FOM 722-6H Case Contacts
Caseworker contact with Supervisor
The caseworker must meet with his/her supervisor at least
monthly for case consultation on every assigned case.
Four of eleven open foster care files reviewed lacked monthly supervision as required.
FOM 801 Health Services for Children in Foster Care
Medical Passports
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
10

Three of eleven open foster care files reviewed lacked completion of the medical
passport as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2019 Interim Inspection Report, CAP approved 1/17/20
2018 Renewal Inspection Report, CAP Approved 1/16/19 (Cited ISEP 6.49)
FOM 722-08E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure, the caseworker must document:
Reason for program/case closure.
One of ten closed files reviewed lacked a closing action summary as required.
SRM 200 Fingerprints
SAT is required to be taken within six months of working in a
position with CW-CHRI access and every two years thereafter.
Eight employees did not complete SAT every two years as required. Four
employees now in a position with CHRI access did not complete SAT within six
months as required.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
The Child Placing Agency rules specific to independent living apply to all youth
residing in an independent living placement. Youth with a legal status of young adult
voluntary foster care who also reside in an independent living placement included.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
The facility was not in need of consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were zero incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. The agency conducted a timely special investigation, and interviewed the
appropriate parties. The foster parent admitted to grabbing the back of a youth’s
neck in response to the youth slamming his computer on the table. The foster
parent self-reported to the agency what had occurred. The agency found the family
in non-compliance where a corrective action plan was required.
11

AND
The facility has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The first was in response to Interim
Inspection completed on December 11, 2019.
The second was in response to Special Investigation 2020C0103040. A
complaint was received that the agency failed to follow up on resident's physical
health at the facility where he was placed. They failed to ensure he was safe and
cared for. The agency was found in non-compliance for Rule 400.12206 Staff
Qualifications as the case manager failed to review the Residential Service Plans,
and Rule 400.12420 as the case manager did not include information in the service
plan from the residential provider. Additional citations included Medical Passports,
face to face contact entry, FTM documentation, and signatures on the parent agency
treatment plan.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan that was approved on
October 21, 2020 where the agency was to train staff on responsibilities, and
documentation requirements now, during orientation, and yearly. Supervisors will
meet with new hires weekly to provide direction, and review documentation in
MiSACWIS prior to approval of service plans including medical passports, FTM
activity reports, and signatures. Home visit checklists are to be turned into
supervisor, documenting signatures. Medical passports will be signed monthly. Staff
and Supervisors will review BOB and maintain quiet time. Program Managers will
review Infoview two times a month for compliance. Pattern of staff non-compliance
may result in disciplinary action.
CAP Compliance Review: I reviewed staff meeting minutes of 10/15/20 that
documented a review of staff responsibilities have occurred. The agency has not
hired any new staff since the corrective action plan was approved, however the
orientation checklist was verified to have been updated and included staff
responsibilities for documentation. Also as no new staff have been hired, weekly
supervision was not able to be verified, yet through review of a random sample of
case files reviewed, staff are often receiving supervision more than once a month. I
interviewed supervisors that reported they are reviewing MiSACWIS during case
service plan review to ensure documents are present. Home visit checklists are
being completed as verified in review of a random sample of case files and uploaded
into MiSACWIS. During interviews with staff and supervisors, quiet hours continue to
be in effect and staff are reviewing the BOB weekly. The agency noted the BOB is
not always accurate due to COVID changes, but they continue to use the tool to
ensure compliance.
During interviews with staff they had a good understanding of the requirements for
timely contacts with clients and corrective action plans in place. Staff were happy
with the support provided by supervision. Staff all reported Catholic Charities West
Michigan has effectively communicated during the pandemic on job responsibilities
12

and ensuring staff safety. During the onsite visit, CHRI storage and disposal was
verified to be in compliance. Personnel files were in full compliance and organized.
VI. DCWL Field Analyst Findings
The information contained in this report section was collected through the interviews
of randomly selected families that are working with Catholic Chartieis West Michigan
Grand Rapids. There were no identified safety concerns.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be
issued a renewal of their regular license.
December 16, 2020
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
December 16, 2020

Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
13
